definition: The part of the enzyme to which a specific substrate can attach or fit on to.
Tiny air sacs in the lungs, where gas is exchanged during breathing.
Basic unit of life. Unicellular organisms only have one cell. Multicellular organisms have many cells.
A carbohydrate. It forms the cell wall in plant cells.
The difference in the concentration of a chemical across a membrane.
The living substance inside a cell (not including the nucleus).
To change the shape of an enzyme's active site, for example because of high temperatures or extremes of pH. Denatured enzymes no longer work.
When an unspecialised cell becomes a more specialised cell type.
The movement of molecules from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.
Using electrons to form images of dead organic matter.
A protein which catalyses or speeds up a chemical reaction.
The basic unit of genetic material inherited from our parents. A gene is a section of DNA which controls part of a cell's chemistry - particularly protein production.
A simple sugar used by cells for respiration.
The amount of matter an object contains. Measured in kilograms (kg) or grams (g).
Having more than one cell.
A group of different tissues that work together to carry out a particular function, eg heart and lungs.
A group of organs that work together to complete a specific function.
The movement of water molecules across a selectively permeable membrane from a region of higher water concentration to a region of lower water concentration.
A measurement that is very different from other measurements taken under the same circumstances in an experiment.
This is the movement of molecules down a concentration gradient without the need for additional energy, eg diffusion and osmosis.
Scale of acidity or alkalinity. A pH (power of hydrogen) value below 7 is acidic, a pH value above 7 is alkaline.
The chemical change that takes place inside living cells, which uses glucose and oxygen to release the energy that organisms need to live. Carbon dioxide is a by-product of respiration.
The property of a membrane that controls the movement of molecules depending on their size.
The dissolved substance in a solution.
The liquid in which the solute dissolves to form a solution.
A type of carbohydrate. Plants can turn the glucose produced in photosynthesis into starch for storage, and turn it back into glucose when it is needed for respiration.
A substance on which enzymes act.
A disaccharide made from glucose and fructose. It is used as table sugar.
A group of similar cells that carry out the same function.
Enlarged and swollen with water. Having turgor. Description of a plant cell in which the vacuole has swollen due to water gain by osmosis.
Finger-like projections in the small intestine that provide a large surface area for the absorption of food.
A fertilised egg cell.
